page.title: 04Housing in Rishton.
page.content: Rishton's houses are typical of an industrial town. The centre is mainly terraced with some new sheltered accommodation. There is a council estate of about 60 houses nearby. The newer privately owned houses are on the outskirts of the town. The older, smaller terraces with small back yards, built for coalplaces and toilets, lie to the south of the High Street and date from 1875 to 1900. Most are brick built with slate roofs. Newer, larger terraces, often with small front gardens were built on the north side between 1890 and 1913. Many have datestones, several with royal connections, e.g. Albert Terrace 1893, Duke of Cambridge Place 1895, and Coronation Terrace 1911. These are mainly built of stone.
